metadata.name: Action Painting #42
metadata.description:
In homage to Jackson Pollock. An algorithmic version of Action Painting.

My Fractions of the Whole algorithm organizes the space frame into areas for a tile comprised of closed paths of bezier line segments with random parameters. An underlying layer is tessellated with tiles made up of closed pathways are filled with a random color; that simulates the chance effects of dripping and spilling paint onto a canvas. Simulating the moving brush-in-hand, nine more iterations the image are overdrawn, each in separate random color, where the shapes are in outline (not filled). The result is a highly dynamic image that simulates the direct, instinctual, and spontaneous application of vigorous, sweeping lines of color.  

Check out Dr. Bill Generative Art OG website @ drbillkolomyjec.com

metadata.name: Cousin Sirko #159
metadata.description:
Cousin Sirko was inspired by a series of OP Art prints done by Victor Vasarely, called Tlinko. (c. 1956) Vasarely died in 1997 in the early days of computer art. I'm sure he would have embraced this medium. This is the seventh in a series of Vasarely inspired Generative Art pieces I am offering.

I became interested in Victor Vasarely's graphic artworks while I was in art school. As I struggled to learn computer graphics I wondered how do I write a program to produce imagery with a similar aesthetic? I call the process of creating algorithms inspired by other artists: "Art"ificial Intelligence.

Cousin Sirko is a black and white composition. It is drawn either with black figures on a white background or vice versa. Its in an optical piece that starts out as a regular field of squares but random smaller areas of squares within the frame are transformed. Transformations to these smaller areas can be rotation, skew, and squash.

The visual phenomena represented here is called differences against a background. My understanding is that in our evolution as humans, when we were all hunters, we learned to see slight differences in a large background such as a forest canopy, grassland or desert. For example, a squirrel moving in the trees or a rabbit through a field of grass. I'm sure there is some psychological term for this but I'll leave that for you to investigate.

Again, there are many Gestalt interactions within this piece. The most prominent being the figure-ground relationship. As well areas of unifying structure. 

By the way my father's sister Juby married George Sirko. As a result I have three cousins named Sirko: Randy, Mary and Daniel.

Dr. Bill Generative Art OG @ drbillkolomyjec.com

metadata.name: Square Dot Composition #283
metadata.description:
Square Dot Composition was inspired by a series of OP Art paintings done by Victor Vasarely, called Planetary Folklore Participations (1960-1969). Vasarely died in 1997 in the early days of computer art. I'm sure he would have embraced this medium. This is the first (the pilot) in a series of Vasarely inspired Generative Art pieces I am offering.

I became interested in Victor Vasarely's graphic artworks while I was in art school. As I struggled to learn computer graphics I wondered how do I write a program to produce imagery with a similar aesthetic? I call the process of creating algorithms inspired by other artists: "Art"ificial Intelligence.

Square Dot Composition is a regular grid of square tiles. The background of each square tile is filled with a random color. A coin-toss algorithm then decides whether to draw another slightly smaller square or circle, in its own random color, centered in the middle of the square. Every iteration is unique and filled with energy. 

Dr. Bill Generative Art OG @ drbillkolomyjec.com

metadata.name: Organic Illusion #97
metadata.description:
Organic Illusion is one of the very first computer graphic drawings I produced that I considered worthy of being called Art. This version is a Plotter Art reconstruction of one of my classics.

Between 1973 - 1975 I was working on an MFA in Graphic Design at Michigan State University. I was using the most rudimentary hardware and software. All graphics were produced by writing code in FORTRAN, punching each line of code into a Hollerith card, assembling cards into a deck and submitting the deck for processing on a main frame at a central computing facility. You returned the next day to pick up your plot which was processed over night on an off-line plotter. I exhibited this piece in my MFA show in 1975.

Back then the only "graphic primitive" we had available to create a drawing was the command to move a pen and draw a line: CALL PLOT(X, Y, penUp) and CALL PLOT(X, Y, penDown). Organic Illusion is an early example of an algorithmic image (non representational/non digitized) employing controlled randomness. It is a regular grid of square tiles that connect. Each tile consists of a square with its perimeter divided into the same number of points as the circle it contains. Randomness determines the placement of the circles‚Äô center relative to the center of the square. The way the coordinate points between the two shapes are connected appear to create a volume, i.e. 3D illusion. 

The code for the original image is long gone but I was able to reconstruct it from memory. Like a child you never forget. I submit to you again in new media for you all to enjoy.

Check out Dr. Bill Generative Art OG website @ drbillkolomyjec.com

metadata.name: menToll #222
metadata.description:
menToll was inspired by a series of OP Art paintings done by Victor Vasarely, called Toll (from the Permutations Series). (c. 1965) Vasarely died in 1997 in the early days of computer art. I'm sure he would have embraced this medium. This is the fifth in a series of Vasarely inspired Generative Art pieces I am offering.

I became interested in Victor Vasarely's graphic artworks while I was in art school. As I struggled to learn computer graphics I wondered how do I write a program to produce imagery with a similar aesthetic? I call the process of creating algorithms inspired by other artists: "Art"ificial Intelligence.

menToll is two layered piece. A 2x2 array of arrays of circles contained within a background square. A similar sized array of squares (with no background of its own) is superimposed and centered on top. Each array of circles with a square has an opacity gradient applied to it allowing its uniquely colored random background to show through its elements. The superimposed top layer of squares is a solid random color.

There are many Gestalt interactions within this piece. Circle groups within each of their containers interact with each other, and their background, in interesting ways. Each new generation with its random color assignments significantly affects your depth perception. The top layer appears to come forward or recede depending on the layer it overlaps. And depending on color combinations there is a variety of "after-imagism" interactions between the squares in the top set. More candy for your mind.

Dr. Bill Generative Art OG @ drbillkolomyjec.com

metadata.name: 3D Crypto Cacti #26
metadata.description:
The 3D Crypto Cacti project is a Tezos based collectible series with unique looks.
Here, on FxHash, it is a 3D rendered, generative, layered PNG project.
The Cacti come in different shapes, colors and sometimes they develop charming or obnoxious personalities.

metadata.name: NO ROADMAP #32
metadata.description:
This collection represents the need we have to move forward despite the obstacles that the road may present us.
We identify ourselves with the one who, even without the most optimal conditions, continues on its way until the goal is reached
Web 3.0 is a space that appears to us without a roadmap, so that everyone can explore it and learn.
Even though we only get to have a skateboard, in this journey of work and effort, we will continue asking ourselves until we can at last get it
WEN LAMBO?

+ 100 Roaders + Color variations
+ 50 Backgrounds + Color variations
+ 30 Foreground
+ 50 Animals
+ 25 Foreground elements
+ 10 Police cars on fire

metadata.name: WTBS: Olympics Poster Edition #191
metadata.description:
WTBS: Olympics Poster Edition is our official collaboration with Jeres, who was kind enough to work with us in support of the show. The project leans into classic Olympic poster design motifs, embellished by Jeres' signature approach to color and shape. Huge thanks to Jeres for donating their time and enthusiasm to this one, we hope you enjoy it!

As with all WTBS projects, your minting will directly support the podcast and keep us going (and more importantly, collecting!). Our goal is to keep the show free from ads and fully supported by the community, your donations and contributions continue to make that possible. Thank you in advance to everyone who chooses to mint!

Jeres: I love vintage posters. When going to second-hand shops, flea markets or wherever people are selling their used goods, I‚Äôm always on the lookout for what people used to hang on their walls. Bauhaus-inspired posters, socialist propaganda, Nagel prints, anything art deco, etc.. but whenever I come across something Olympics inspired I always feel like I hit pay dirt. There‚Äôs something about the clean, simple design being used to show people coming together along with the undertones of human excellence that just feels special. And circles. I love circles. I hope you enjoy this collection as much as I enjoyed putting it together with Trinity and Will.

Approximate rarity notes:
5%: Gold Edition
10%: Silver Edition
15%: Bronze Edition 

Commands in fullscreen mode:
S : Save current resolution
1 : Save 2000x3000px
2 : Save 4000x6000px
3 : Save 6000x9000px
4 : Save 8000x12000px
5 : Save 10000x15000px

(The higher the resolution, the longer it takes to render/save. use Chrome for best results.)

metadata.name: Salem #121
metadata.description:
A formerly human witch, Salem Saberhagen was sentenced by the Witch's Council to spend 100 years as a cat, as punishment for trying to take over the world. 

Details: Layered composition - *1600pix - 91 layers - hand-drawn pieces

metadata.name: Unless it falls apart #161
metadata.description:
"(This) is all we're gonna get
Unless it falls apart
So I say: go go go, go down
Let it fall down
I'm ready for the end." 


-------

CONTROLS:
Press `s` to download a PNG file.
Press `h` to generate a 4500x6750 image.
Press `n` to disable the grain texture.

-------

Made with p5.js and the help of a GLSL shader.

See license.md for licensing details.

metadata.name: a working theory #57
metadata.description:
Initial conditions are stated, and then the particles set in motion - the root of generative art. My goal with this piece was to create an illustration that seemed to be from an earlier (or perhaps later?) time; not, at any rate, our current moment. The background is a very subtle gradient; then it is heavily stippled, and followed with a particle system to create more subtle texture. (Look for the very small "hairs" in the background; they are more obvious on the dark ones. They are a subset of the main particle system.) 

Following that, the main particle system is run in real time; I like to "show my work" for generative pieces, as any collector of my previous mints knows, and this is no exception. "Run" your mint for an animated drawing experience. Note that fxpreview() hits a few frames before the end of the full run. I did it this way to ensure a consistent preview. As a result, the preview and the final image will be slightly different, only because the final image has a slightly longer lifespan. 

There are multiple "special" modes, each with a 10% likelihood: 

"spiral" will rotate the canvas as the particle system is running.
"chaos" uses random X/Y vectors during the acceleration phase, rather than X or Y.
"occasionals" adds random large particles in an opposing color.

In addition, there are three possible shapes:

"circle" draws circles for the particles.
"square" draws squares for the particles.
"jagged" draws mostly circles, with a 0.01% chance of a square at a 45 degree angle. 

Finally, there is a non-attribute feature, where the entire piece is drawn at a 45 degree angle. This has a 20% likelihood, but is only apparent on pieces that have no special, or the "occasional" special. Working the math out, you have a 16% likelihood for getting a piece at a noticeable 45 degree angle. 

All main colors have an equal likelihood, but the light background is only 20%.

metadata.name: Teal Iron Elaphrosaurus #4
metadata.description:
"Teal Iron Elaphrosaurus" is part of an ongoing series of experiments combining hand-drawn "squiggles" and turning them into something unexpected.

Please be patient. It will take a couple of seconds for the image to render.

They are written by hand with Sharpies and p5.js.

metadata.name: Juxtaposition #1
metadata.description:
This is the third in series of works where we pay homage to Ken Knowlton, scientist and computer graphic pioneer and artist who passed on June 16, 2022. Ken Knowlton developed the famous EXPLOR language, (Explicit 2-D Patterns, Local Operations, and Randomness) while at Bell Labs. He published a paper describing it in 1975 entitled: MINI-EXPLOR, A FORTRAN-Coded Version of the EXPLOR Language for Mini (and larger) Computers. (https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/988049.988052)

This work is a mark of progress. Christopher Scussel and I are working on modernizing MINI-EXPLOR. Chris is working on updating the engine from the original FORTRAN code of the 1970‚Äôs and its other limitations to usable JavaScript. In concert, I am analyzing and synthesizing the capabilities of the code and identifying an aesthetic. Together we continue to update EXPLOR and add new features.

Juxtaposition is based on Randomly Oriented Juxtaposed Modules (Test Example 1) that was published in Knowlton's paper describing MINI-EXPLOR in 1975. 

The image is built up in layers. The first or background layer is drawn using randomly placed and sized areas of the picture space using EXPLOR‚Äôs CHANJ function. It breaks the background up into areas of color.

The second layer is a regular grid of juxtaposed tiles. To create more figure-ground relationships a tile is drawn only 67% of the time. The tile in this piece consists of a 7x7 block of cells is defined by the artist. This particular tile was constructed to represent a quarter circle of colored rings. Initially this tile needs to be placed in the image (it's in the upper right corner). It is this tile or, block of cells, that is cloned and manipulated using EXPLOR‚Äôs COMBN function. The COMBN function does more than just copy the block and place it, it has an extensive parameter list that determines what happens to the color of each cell relative to the block of cells placement (a set of rules) and it can orient the tile in 8 predefined ways. Applying randomness to the function's parameters causes a simple or complicated ‚Äúcombination‚Äù of two picture areas.  

The last layer is subject to chance and is only executed 25% of the time. I run the background layer algorithm over the image one more time using another set of rules to alter the existing colors of all the cells in the image. Making the image even more complex and chaotic.

In keeping true to an EXPLOR vibe we use 4 color palettes. We let the computer randomly pick from three predefined palettes: Black and white. Four colors randomly chosen from set of 8 ‚ÄúBauhaus‚Äù colors. And, four truly random colors.

We continue to honor the passing of Ken Knowlton with this NFT series. Here is an opportunity to collect an example image from the famous program he authored now updated by Scussel and Kolomyjec. A true piece of Computer Graphic Art history with a modern twist.

(c)2022 Dr. Bill Kolomyjec and Christoper Scussel. All rights reserved.
